column1: Racine ( rə-SEEN) is a city in and the county seat of Racine County
column3: United States. It is located on the shore of Lake Michigan at the mouth of the Root River.  Racine is located 22 miles south of Milwaukee and is part of the Greater Milwaukee Area. As of the 2010 U.S. census
column4: the city had a population of 78
column6: making it the fifth-largest city in Wisconsin. Its median home price of $103
column7: 625 makes it one of the most affordable cities in Wisconsin to buy a home.  In January 2017
column8: it was rated "the most affordable place to live in the world" by the Demographia International Housing Affordability survey.Racine is the headquarters of a number of industries
column9: including J. I. Case heavy equipment
column10: S. C. Johnson & Son cleaning and chemical products
column12: Reliance Controls Corporation time controls and transfer switches
column14: and Arthur B. Modine heat exchangers. The Mitchell & Lewis Company
column16: began making motorcycles and automobiles as Mitchell-Lewis Motor Company at the start of the 20th century. Racine is also home to InSinkErator
column17: manufacturers of the first garbage disposal. Racine was also historically home to the Horlicks malt factory
column18: where malted milk balls were first developed
column19: and the Western Publishing factory where Little Golden Books were printed. Prominent architects in Racine's history include A. Arthur Guilbert and Edmund Bailey Funston
column20: and the city is home to several works by Frank Lloyd Wright. It has several immigrant communities
column21: and is among the most diverse cities in Wisconsin.

column1: Native Americans inhabited the area of Racine for thousands of years. Artifacts that have survived include the burial mounds in what is now Mound Cemetery. Historians separate the natives living in the Root watershed at that time into Woodland people and Hopewell people. After European contact
column2: the Miami and later the Potawatomi expanded into the area
column3: taking part in the French fur trade.

column2: while traveling from Green Bay to the territory of the Illinois Confederation
column3: Father Jacques Marquette and his assistants
column4: Jacques Largillier and Pierre Porteret
column5: camped at the mouth of the Root River. These were the first Europeans known to visit what is now Racine County. Further expeditions were made in the area by René-Robert Cavelier
column6: Sieur de La Salle in 1679 and by François Jolliet De Montigny and Jean Baptiste Bissot
column7: Sieur de Vincennes in 1698. Nearly a century later
column9: a trading post would be established along Lake Michigan near where the Root River empties into it.

column4: was settled by Yankees from upstate New York and New England. In 1834 Captain Gilbert Knapp USRM
column5: who was from Chatham
column7: founded the settlement of "Port Gilbert" at the place where the Root River empties into Lake Michigan. Knapp had first explored the area of the Root River valley in 1818
column8: and returned with financial backing when the war ended. Within a year of Knapp's settlement hundreds of other settlers from New England and western New York had arrived and built log cabins in the area surrounding his own.  Some of the settlers were from the town of Derby
column10: and others came from the New England states of Connecticut
column13: New Hampshire and Maine.  The area was previously called "Kipi Kawi" and "Chippecotton" by the indigenous peoples
column14: both names for the Root River. The name "Port Gilbert" was never really accepted
column15: and in 1841 the community was incorporated as the village of Racine
column16: after the French word for "root". After Wisconsin was admitted to the Union in 1848
column17: the new legislature voted in August to incorporate Racine as a city.

column4: was founded; it closed in 1933. Its location and many of its buildings are preserved today by the Community of St. Mary as part of the DeKoven Center.

column3: the first public high school in Wisconsin
column4: opened. The high school operated until 1926
column5: when it was torn down to make way for the new Racine County Courthouse. Washington Park High School was built to replace it.Before the Civil War
column6: Racine was well known for its strong opposition to slavery
column7: with many slaves escaping to freedom via the Underground Railroad passing through the city. In 1854 Joshua Glover
column8: an escaped slave who had made a home in Racine
column9: was arrested by federal marshals and jailed in Milwaukee. One hundred men from Racine
column12: rallied and broke into the jail to free him. He was helped to escape to Canada. Glover's rescue gave rise to many legal complications and a great deal of litigation. This eventually led to the Wisconsin Supreme Court declaring the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 unconstitutional
column14: the Wisconsin State Legislature refusing to recognize the authority of the U.S. Supreme Court.

column4: and Czechs
column5: began to settle in Racine between the Civil War and the First World War. African Americans started arriving in large numbers during World War I
column6: as they did in other Midwestern industrial towns
column7: and Hispanics migrated to Racine from roughly 1925 onward.

column2: Episcopalians and Congregationalists from New England initially dominated Racine's religious life. Racine's Emmaus Lutheran Church
column3: the oldest Danish Lutheran Church in North America
column4: was founded on August 22
column5: 1851. Originally a founding member of the Danish American Lutheran Church
column6: it has subsequently been a member of the United Danish Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (UDELCA)
column10: the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA). There was also a large Catholic movement to the city
column11: opening up churches for their own ethnicity
column27: forming St. Richard. With new waves of people arriving
column28: older parishes received a boost from the Hispanic community
column30: re-energizing St. Patrick's into the strong Catholic community of today.

column1: Racine has the largest North American settlement of Danes outside of Greenland. The city has become known for its Danish pastries
column2: particularly kringle. Several local bakeries have been featured on the Food Network highlighting the pastry. In June 2010
column3: President Barack Obama stopped at an O & H Danish Bakery before hosting a town hall meeting on the economy and jobs later that afternoon.

column1: Racine was a factory town almost from the beginning. The first industry in Racine County included the manufacture of fanning mills
column2: machines that separate wheat grain from chaff. Racine also had its share of captains of industry
column4: S. C. Johnson & Son (cleaning and chemical products)
column5: and Arthur B. Modine (Heat Exchangers). Racine's harbor was central to the shipping industry in Wisconsin in the late 19th century. Racine was also an early car manufacturing center. One of the world's first automobiles was built there in 1871 or 1872 by Dr. J. W. Cathcart
column6: as was the Pennington Victoria tricycle
column9: malted milk was invented in Racine by English immigrant William Horlick
column10: and Horlicks remains a global brand. The garbage disposal was invented in 1927 by architect John Hammes of Racine
column12: which still produces millions of garbage disposers every year in Racine. Racine is also the home of S.C. Johnson & Son
column13: whose headquarters were designed in 1936 by Frank Lloyd Wright. Wright also designed the Wingspread Conference Center and several homes and other buildings in Racine. The city is also home to the Dremel Corporation
column14: Reliance Controls Corporation and  Twin Disc.  Case New Holland’s Racine manufacturing facility
column15: which builds two types of tractors (the New Holland T8 and the Case IH Magnum)
column16: offers public tours throughout the year.

column1: Racine includes the Old Main Street Historic District. Historic buildings in Racine include the Badger Building

column1: Frank Lloyd Wright designed and built the Johnson Wax Headquarters building in Racine. The building was and still is considered a marvel of design innovation
column2: despite its many practical annoyances such as rainwater leaks. Wright urged then-president Hib Johnson to build the structure outside of Racine
column4: a Wisconsin native
column5: thought of as "backwater." Johnson refused to have the Johnson Wax Headquarters sited anywhere other than Racine.

column1: Racine has a warm-summer Continental climate (Köppen climate classification: Dfb). Summers are warm and short while winters are cold. Precipitation is dispersed evenly throughout the year
column2: although summers are slightly wetter and more humid than winters.

column2: the systematic use of partnerships and problem-solving techniques to address the immediate conditions that give rise to crime. The number of crimes committed in the city in 2013 dropped in several categories to the lowest point in decades. Racine saw a 38.3 percent drop in violent crime from 2009 to 2013
column3: making it the 10th largest decrease in the country. Property crimes were at their lowest point since 1965
column4: while the number of violent crimes was the lowest for any year on record.However
column5: that trend has since changed. As of 2018
column6: the chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime in Racine is 1 in 37
column7: thus making the city's crime rate higher than 92% of Wisconsin's other cities and towns.

column1: Racine's municipal water is drawn from Lake Michigan. In 2011
column2: the city's water was named the best tasting tap water in the United States by a panel of the U.S. Conference of Mayors.

column1: Racine has a mayor-council form of government. The mayor is the chief executive
column2: elected for a term of four years. The mayor appoints commissioners and other officials who oversee the departments
column3: subject to Common Council approval. On October 17
column5: Cory Mason was elected as mayor of Racine
column6: completing the term of John Dickert.

column1: Racine's other citywide elected official is the Municipal Judge. The city council
column4: one elected from each district in the city. The council enacts local ordinances and approves the city budget. Government priorities and activities are established in a budget ordinance usually adopted each November. Being a diverse community with a history of organized labor
column5: the city predominantly votes for the Democratic Party (United States). The City's youngest City Council President was Tom Mortenson
column7: who was a leading Progressive Republican who led ethical reform that served as a model for other municipal governments.

column1: Racine is represented by Bryan Steil (R) in the United States House of Representatives
column2: and by Ron Johnson (R) and Tammy Baldwin (D) in the United States Senate. Robert Wirch (D) and Van H. Wanggaard (R) represent Racine in the Wisconsin State Senate
column4: Peter Barca (D)
column5: and Greta Neubauer (D) represent Racine in the Wisconsin State Assembly.

column1: Fire protection and ambulance service is provided by the city of Racine fire department. Police services are provided by the Racine police department and Racine County Sheriff.
Racine's public schools are administered by the Racine Unified School District
column4: and six high schools with a combined student enrollment of around 17
column5: 500. Programs such as International Baccalaureate and Montessori are widely utilized in the District.

column1: Private schools in the city include:
Wisconsin Lutheran Middle SchoolThe Prairie School is in nearby Wind Point. It was co-founded by Imogene "Gene" Powers Johnson

column1: University of Wisconsin–Parkside is located south of Racine in the Town of Somers. Prior to Parkside's creation there were state college campuses in both Racine and Kenosha
column2: but with their proximity it was decided they would be better served by one larger campus in between the two cities. A campus of Gateway Technical College
column3: which serves the tri-county area of the southeastern corner of Wisconsin
column4: is located in the downtown district on Lake Michigan.

column1: Mass transit is provided by the Belle Urban System or "BUS" for short. Taxi service is provided by Racine Taxi.Racine is also served by Amtrak's Hiawatha Line from the Sturtevant station in Racine County.  Additional train service to Chicago is provided by Metra's Union Pacific/North Line from the downtown Kenosha station
column2: which is located 6 miles from the Racine County line and 11 miles from downtown Racine.

column1: Batten International Airport (KRAC) is a public use airport located in Racine
column2: and the largest privately-owned airport in the United States.  Racine is one of only three Wisconsin cities
column3: along with Milwaukee and Green Bay
column4: to have airports with customs intake capabilities.  Commercial air service is provided by O'Hare International Airport and General Mitchell International Airport.

column1: Racine is nationally known for its 4 July Parade. The 4th Fest Parade in Racine is the Largest in the Midwest. 4th Fest of Greater Racine
column2: Inc. is a non-profit organization with an entirely volunteer board of directors. This group is responsible for all celebratory activities in Racine associated with the 4th of July. In 2008
column3: USA Today ranked Racine's 4th Fest Parade as one of the Top 10 Places to celebrate the 4th of July.

column2: a professional football team and part of the National Football League
column3: played here from 1922 to 1924. Its official name was the Horlick-Racine Legion. The team then operated as the Racine Tornadoes in 1926. They played at Horlick Field.

column1: The city is known for its large prom celebration
column2: at which students from all the high schools in the city participate in an after prom party. This was featured on the radio show This American Life in Episode #186 "Prom"
column4: 2001; Racine's prom tradition was also the subject of the 2006 documentary The World's Best Prom. In addition to the large prom Racine has become known for
column5: the city has also been hosting a special needs prom called A Night To Remember every year since 2013. The A Night To Remember prom always takes place on the Sunday following Racine's larger prom and includes those from age 13 to 30.

column1: Racine is served by the daily newspaper The Journal Times
column2: which is the namesake (but not current owner) of radio station WRJN (1400). The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel formerly published a Racine-specific page on Thursdays and a Racine County section on Sundays
column3: but dropped those in a series of downsizings that began in 2007. The Insider News covers issues specific to the African-American community. Racinenews.org offers web-based coverage for Racine.The city has one television station owned by Weigel Broadcasting
column4: WMLW-TV (Channel 49)
column5: an independent station which airs syndicated product
column6: and had its analog transmitter just north of the Milwaukee County line in Oak Creek. For all intents and purposes the station serves all of southeastern Wisconsin
column7: with the station offices located in West Allis and the station's current transmitter is located on the Weigel tower in Milwaukee's Lincoln Park. WMLW airs a Saturday morning public affairs program called Racine & Me
column8: which is produced and hosted by Jessica Tighe of sister station WDJT-TV
column9: and is devoted to topics of interest to Racine residents. The station's fourth subchannel also rebroadcasts Telemundo affiliate WYTU-LD.

column1: FM radio stations serving the area are country music WVTY (92.1 FM) and urban contemporary WKKV-FM (100.7). WVTY specifically targets Racine and Kenosha and is locally owned
column2: while WKKV is a station owned by iHeartMedia that
column3: although licensed to Racine and having a transmitter in north-central Racine County
column4: is targeted towards Milwaukee audiences and has its offices in Greenfield. Sturtevant-licensed WDDW-FM (104.7) broadcasts a traditional Mexican music format targeting the metro area's Mexican-American population.
